lg.l: A man with Expence of wonderfull Toile
by planting and dunging Enobled his Soile
There friuts of the best the tast did invite
And in this form order Still Courted ye Sight
No degenerate weed the rich ground did produce
And all things afforded both beauty and Use
Till from Dunghill transplanted while yett but a Seed
A nettle rear'd up his inglorius head
The Gard'ner would wisely have rooted him up
To Stop the increase of a barbarous Crop
But the master forbad and after the fashion
of foolish good Nature and blind morderation
forbore him thro' pitty and chose as much rather
To ask him some questions first, how he came thither
Kind Sir quothe the nettle a Stranger I co overame
For Consience compell'd to relinquish my home
Cause I would not Subscribe to a mystery dark
That the Prince of all trees was the Jesuits bark
An Erroneous tenet, I know Sir that you:Know more then my Self will allow to be true
To you I for refuge and Sanctuary Sue
Theres none So renown'd for compassion as you
And tho in Some things I may differ from these
The rest of the faithfull and beautifull trees
Tho' your digging and dunging my nature much harm
and I cannot comply with the gardner in form
Yet I and our family after ye fashion
will peacably Stick to our own Education
Be pleased to allow us a place for to rest in
mongst the rest of your trees we'll never molest 'em
A kind Shelter to us and protection afford
WeÂ·'ll do you no harm I'll give you my word
The good man was soon won by this plausible tale
So fraud on good nature does often prevail
He wellcomes his guest gives him free tolleration
In the midst of his garden to take up his Station
And into his bosom does his enemy bring
He never suspected the Nettle would StingStill flush'd with Success of Strength to be fear'd
around him a numerous offspring he rear'd
Then the Master grew Sensible what he had done
And faine would have had his new guest to be gone
But now 'twas too late to bid him turn out
A well rooted possession already was got
The old trees decay'd and in there room grew
A Stubborn rank pistilent poysonous crew
The master who first that young brood had admitted
They Stung like Ingrates and left him unpitied
no hilp from manuring and planting was found
The weeds had eat out the heart of the ground
Thus one nettle uncropt encreas'd to Such Store
That 'twas nothing but weeds what was garden beforeX85-270L
